sen.j: 初詣（はつもうで）とは、年が明けてから初めて寺社（神社・寺院）や教会などに参拝し、一年の無事と平安を祈る行事である。
sen.e: Hatsumode is an event to pray for safety and peace for the year by visiting a shrine or temple (a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple), or church for the first time since the start of a new year.
Hatsumode is an event to pray for safety and peace for the year by visiting a shrine or temple (a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple), or church for the first time since the start of a new year.
Hatsumode is an event to pray for safety and peace for the year by visiting a shrine or temple (a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple), or church for the first time since the start of a new year.

sen.j: 初参り（はつまいり）ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called "hatsumairi" (literally, "first visit to the shrine").
It is also called hatsumairi (literally, first visit to the shrine).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。
sen.e: It is also called hatsumairi (literally, first visit to the shrine).

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 元々は「年蘢り」（としこもり、としごもり）と言い、家長が祈願のために大晦日の夜から元日の朝にかけて氏神の社に蘢る習慣であった。
sen.e: Originally this was a custom called "toshikomori" (or "toshigomori") in which the head of a family shut himself away in the shrine of the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) from the night of New Year's Eve until the morning of New Year's Day to offer prayers.

Originally this was a custom called 'toshikomori' (also referred as toshigomori) in which the head of a family shut himself away in the shrine of the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) from the night of New Year's Eve until the morning of New Year's Day to offer prayers.

Originally this was a custom called 'toshikomori' (also referred as toshigomori) in which the head of a family shut himself away in the shrine of the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) from the night of New Year's Eve until the morning of New Year's Day to offer prayers.

sen.j: やがて年蘢りは、大晦日の夜の「除夜詣」と元日の朝の「元日詣」との2つに分かれ、元日詣が今日の初詣の原形となった。
sen.e: Eventually toshikomori separated into "joyamode", in which the visit was made on the night of the New Year's Eve, and the "ganjitsumode", in which the visit was made on the morning of the New Year's Day, and ganjitsumode became the original form of today's hatsumode.

Eventually toshikomori was divided into two customs; 'joyamode,' the visit in the night of New Year's Eve, and 'ganjitsumode,' that in the morning of the New Year's Day, which became the original form of today's hatsumode.

Eventually toshikomori was divided into two customs; 'joyamode,' the visit in the night of New Year's Eve, and 'ganjitsumode,' that in the morning of the New Year's Day, which became the original form of today's hatsumode.

sen.j: 江戸時代末期までは氏神またはその年の恵方の方角の社寺に詣でること（恵方詣り）が多かったのだが、明治以降では氏神や恵方とは関係なく有名な寺社への参詣が普通になっている。
sen.e: Up until the end of the Edo period, it was common for one to go to a shrine or temple of the ujigami, or a shrine or temple in the direction of the eho ("lucky direction") for the year (this custom was called "ehomairi"); but after the Meiji period, it became customary for one to visit a well-known shrine or temple regardless of the ujigami or eho.

Up until the end of the Edo period, it was common to visit the shrine or temple of ujigami or those in the direction of his or her eho (lucky direction) for the year (ehomairi), but after the Meiji period, it became customary to visit a well-known shrine or temple, regardless of the ujigami or eho.

Up until the end of the Edo period, it was common to visit the shrine or temple of ujigami or those in the direction of his or her eho (lucky direction) for the year (ehomairi), but after the Meiji period, it became customary to visit a well-known shrine or temple, regardless of the ujigami or eho.

sen.j: また現在でも、除夜に一度氏神に参拝して一旦家に帰り、元旦になって再び参拝するという地方がある。
sen.e: Even today, there are areas where people pay a visit to the ujigami on the New Year's Eve and go home once, and then pay another visit on the New Year's Day.
Even today, there are regions where people visit the ujigami on the New Year's Eve and go home once, then visit again on the New Year's Day.
Even today, there are regions where people visit the ujigami on the New Year's Eve and go home once, then visit again on the New Year's Day.

sen.j: これを二年参りという。
sen.e: This custom is called "ninen-mairi" ("a two-year visit to a shrine").
This custom is called ninen-mairi (a two-year visit to a shrine).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを削除しました。
sen.e: This custom is called ninen-mairi (a two-year visit to a shrine).

sen.j: 初詣が習慣化したのはそれほど古い時代ではなく、明治時代中期のこととされている。
sen.e: Hatsumode is considered to have become a common practice not so long ago but during the middle of the Meiji period.
Hatsumode is considered to have become a common practice not so long ago but during the middle of the Meiji period.
Hatsumode is considered to have become a common practice not so long ago but during the middle of the Meiji period.

sen.j: 明治時代初期までは恵方詣りの風習が残っていたようだが、京阪神において鉄道事業者が沿線の神社仏閣をてんでんばらばらに「今年の恵方は○○だ」と宣伝し始めたために、本来の恵方ではない神社仏閣にも詣でるようになり、恵方の意味が薄れ、有名な神社仏閣にお参りするようになったといわれている。
sen.e: It is said that, up until the early part of the Meiji period, some still practiced the custom of ehomairi; however, as railway companies in the Keihanshin area (namely, Osaka, Kyoto, and Kobe Cities) began to randomly advertise the shrines and temples along their own railway lines by saying that "the eho for the year is XX", people began to visit shrines and temples which were not rightfully in the direction of eho, thus causing the meaning of eho to fade away and people began to visit well-known shrines and temples.

It is said that, up until the early Meiji period, some still practiced the custom of ehomairi; however, as each railway company in the Keihanshin region (namely, Osaka, Kyoto, and Kobe) started to advertise the shrines and temples of their choice along their own railway lines, by saying that 'the eho for the year is XX,' people became to visit those in other than the actual eho direction which leads the meaning of eho fade away and people visit well-known shrines and temples.

It is said that, up until the early Meiji period, some still practiced the custom of ehomairi; however, as each railway company in the Keihanshin region (namely, Osaka, Kyoto, and Kobe) started to advertise the shrines and temples of their choice along their own railway lines, by saying that 'the eho for the year is XX,' people became to visit those in other than the actual eho direction which leads the meaning of eho fade away and people visit well-known shrines and temples.

sen.j: 関東においても、京成電鉄や京浜急行電鉄、成田鉄道（現・JR成田線）など、参拝客輸送を目的として開業された鉄道会社が存在する。
sen.e: In Kanto area, too, railway companies such as Keisei Electric Railway Co., Ltd., Keihin Electric Express Railway Co., Ltd., and Narita Railway (the current JR Narita Line) were established for the purpose of transporting visitors to shrines and temples.

In Kanto region, too, railway companies such as Keisei Electric Railway Co., Ltd., Keihin Electric Express Railway Co., Ltd., and Narita Railway (the current JR Narita Line) were established for the purpose of transporting visitors to shrines and temples.
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。
sen.e: In Kanto region, too, railway companies such as Keisei Electric Railway Co., Ltd., Keihin Electric Express Railway Co., Ltd., and Narita Railway (the current JR Narita Line) were established for the purpose of transporting visitors to shrines and temples.

sen.j: 基本的に「年蘢り」形式を踏まず、単に寺社に「元日詣」を行うだけの初詣は明治以降広まった新しい風習であり、それも鉄道網の発展による賜物という。
sen.e: Fundamentally, hatsumode, in which no "toshigomori" formalities are taken but only "ganjitsumode" to shrines and temples is conducted, is a new custom which became widespread after the Meiji period; this is considered as being the product resulting from development of the railway network.

Fundamentally, hatsumode, in which no 'toshigomori' formalities are taken but only 'ganjitsumode' to shrines and temples is conducted, is a new custom which became widespread after the Meiji period; this is considered as being the product resulting from development of the railway network.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。
sen.e: Fundamentally, hatsumode, in which no 'toshigomori' formalities are taken but only 'ganjitsumode' to shrines and temples is conducted, is a new custom which became widespread after the Meiji period; this is considered as being the product resulting from development of the railway network.

sen.j: 寺社へ参拝をし、社務所でお守り、破魔矢、風車 (玩具)、熊手などを買ったり、絵馬に願い事や目標を書いたり、おみくじを引いたりして、今年一年がよい年であるよう祈る。
sen.e: One goes to a shrine or temple and prays that the year be good for him, in addition to purchasing articles such as omamori (a personal amulet), hamaya (a ritual arrow to drive away devils), windmill (a toy), and kumade (a rake-shaped amulet) at shrine offices, writing wishes and intentions on ema (a votive horse tablet), and drawing sacred lots (fortune slips).

People visit a shrine or temple to pray that the year is good for them by purchasing such as omamori (a personal amulet), hamaya (a ritual arrow to drive away devils), windmill (a toy), and kumade (a rake-shaped amulet) at the shrine or temple offices, writing wishes and intentions on ema (a votive horse tablet), and drawing sacred lots.

People visit a shrine or temple to pray that the year is good for them by purchasing such as omamori (a personal amulet), hamaya (a ritual arrow to drive away devils), windmill (a toy), and kumade (a rake-shaped amulet) at the shrine or temple offices, writing wishes and intentions on ema (a votive horse tablet), and drawing sacred lots.

sen.j: 昨年のお守りや破魔矢などは、このときに寺社に納めて焼いてもらう。
sen.e: One can bring the omamori and hamaya, etc., for the past year to be stored in the shrine or temple where they are burned.
The last year's omamori and hamaya, and so on, are dedicated to the shrine or temple to be burned.
The last year's omamori and hamaya, and so on, are dedicated to the shrine or temple to be burned.

sen.j: また境内では甘酒や神酒が振るわれ、飲むと厄除けになるとされる。
sen.e: Also, amazake (sweet mild sake) and omiki (sacred wine or sake) are offered in the precincts of shrines and temples, and drinking them is said to ward off evil fortune.
Also, amazake (sweet mild sake) and omiki (sacred wine or sake) offered in the precincts are said to expel evil by drinking them.
Also, amazake (sweet mild sake) and omiki (sacred wine or sake) offered in the precincts are said to expel evil by drinking them.

sen.j: 各地の初詣の模様は、12月31日より1月1日早朝にかけて日本放送協会NHK総合テレビジョンの長寿番組「ゆく年くる年」などで毎年中継されている。
sen.e: Hatsumode in various areas are broadcast every year from December 31 until the early morning of January 1 in programs such as a long-running program called "Yukutoshi -Kurutoshi" ("the old year and the new year") by Nippon Hoso Kyokai (Japan Broadcasting Corporation).

Hatsumode in various areas are broadcast every year from December 31 until the early morning of January 1 in the programs such as a long-running program called 'Yukutoshi -Kurutoshi' (the old year and the new year) by Nippon Hoso Kyokai (Japan Broadcasting Corporation).
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。
sen.e: Hatsumode in various areas are broadcast every year from December 31 until the early morning of January 1 in the programs such as a long-running program called 'Yukutoshi -Kurutoshi' (the old year and the new year) by Nippon Hoso Kyokai (Japan Broadcasting Corporation).

sen.j: なお、初詣の対象は神社・寺院のいずれでもかまわないとされている。
sen.e: It is said that the target of hatsumode can be either a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple.
It is said that the target of hatsumode can be either a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple.
It is said that the target of hatsumode can be either a Shinto shrine or Buddhist temple.

sen.j: これは明治時代初期に神仏分離が行われる前は、神道と大乗仏教、ならびに祖霊信仰が一体化した神仏習合による信仰が一般化していたためである。
sen.e: This is because during the early period of the Meiji period, before the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism, the belief based on syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism wherein Shinto, Mahayana Buddhism, and Sorei shinko (belief in ancestral spirits) were unified, had become customary.

This is because before the separation of Buddhism and Shinto in the early Meiji period, the belief based on syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism with the integration of Shinto, Mahayana Buddhism, and Sorei shinko (belief in ancestral spirits), was common.

This is because before the separation of Buddhism and Shinto in the early Meiji period, the belief based on syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism with the integration of Shinto, Mahayana Buddhism, and Sorei shinko (belief in ancestral spirits), was common.

sen.j: つまり、初詣に限らず寺社への参詣に神道･仏教の区別は無いとされていたことの名残である。
sen.e: In other words, this is a remnant of the idea of making no distinction between Shinto and Buddhism regarding the visit to temples and shrines, not only in the case of hatsumode.

In other words, the idea that, from a Shinto or Buddhism perspective, no distinction is made between whether you visit a shrine (a Shinto place of worship) or temple (a Buddhist place of worship) remains today, and this applies not only to hatsumode, but to other cases as well.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせて訳文を修正
sen.e: In other words, the idea that, from a Shinto or Buddhism perspective, no distinction is made between whether you visit a shrine (a Shinto place of worship) or temple (a Buddhist place of worship) remains today, and this applies not only to hatsumode, but to other cases as well.

sen.j: 初詣を行う年齢層にはバラつきがあり、ノーリツが2006年12月に行ったインターネット上のアンケートでは、初詣に毎年行くと答えた年齢層の割合は70歳以上が59.1%だったのに対し、20歳代では44.4%に留まっている。
sen.e: The age group for going to hatsumode varies; according to a questionnaire on the Internet which was conducted by Noriz in December of 2006, the percentage of people who responded that they go to hatsumode every year was 59.1% for the age group of "70's or above", whereas 44.4% for the age group of "20's".

The age group for hatsumode varies; according to a questionnaire on the Internet conducted by Noriz in December 2006, the percentage of people who responded to go hatsumode every year was 59.1 percent for the age group of 70's or above, whereas 44.4 percent for the age group of 20's.

The age group for hatsumode varies; according to a questionnaire on the Internet conducted by Noriz in December 2006, the percentage of people who responded to go hatsumode every year was 59.1 percent for the age group of 70's or above, whereas 44.4 percent for the age group of 20's.

sen.j: さらに20歳未満では75%がほとんど行かないと回答している（産経新聞2006年12月18日の記事より）。
sen.e: As for the age group of "20's or below", 75% responded that they hardly ever go to hatsumode (from an article dated December 18 in the Sankei Shimbun).
As for the age group of 20's or below, 75 percent responded that they hardly ever go to hatsumode (from an article dated December 18, 2006, in the Sankei Shinbun Newspaper).
As for the age group of 20's or below, 75 percent responded that they hardly ever go to hatsumode (from an article dated December 18, 2006, in the Sankei Shinbun Newspaper).

sen.j: このためか、若年層向けの雑誌では初詣特集にもかかわらず、初詣の後の食事や買い物を取り上げ、初詣そのものはメインにしないものも存在している。
sen.e: This is probably the reason behind some magazines, which target the young, to pick up the meals and shopping after hatsumode instead of focusing on the hatsumode itself, in spite of being special issues for hatsumode.

This is probably the reason behind some magazines for the young to pick up the meals and shopping after hatsumode instead of focusing on the hatsumode itself, in spite of being feature article on hatsumode.

This is probably the reason behind some magazines for the young to pick up the meals and shopping after hatsumode instead of focusing on the hatsumode itself, in spite of being feature article on hatsumode.

sen.j: 初詣には、特に定められた規定は無い。
sen.e: There is no special definition for hatsumode.
There is no special definition for hatsumode.
There is no special definition for hatsumode.

sen.j: これは日本人が基本的に宗教に寛容な民族である事に由来する。
sen.e: This originates from the fact that the Japanese are basically peoples with a very generous view on religion.
This originates from the fact that the Japanese basically have a very generous view on religion.
This originates from the fact that the Japanese basically have a very generous view on religion.

sen.j: 一般的に、正月三が日に参拝するのを初詣といっているが、1月中に参拝すれば特に問題はないともいう。
sen.e: Generally, hatsumode refers to the visit made during the first three days of the New Year, but it is also said that there is no special problem if the visit is made sometime in January.
Generally, hatsumode refers to the visit made during the first three days of the New Year, but it is also said that there is no special problem if the visit is made sometime in January.
Generally, hatsumode refers to the visit made during the first three days of the New Year, but it is also said that there is no special problem if the visit is made sometime in January.

sen.j: また、回数に関する規定も無い。
sen.e: Also, there is no definition for the number of hatsumode.
Also, there is no definition for the number of hatsumode.
Also, there is no definition for the number of hatsumode.

sen.j: 多数の神社仏閣に参詣すれば色々なご利益があるという説もあり、その場合神社・仏閣を特に問わない。
sen.e: According to one theory, one can expect many blessings if he pays visits to many shrines and temples; in such case, the visits can be made to either Shinto shrines or Buddhist temples.
According to one theory, the more Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples you visit, the greater the blessing you receive, but whether you visit shrines or temples doesn't really matter.
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせて訳文を修正
sen.e: According to one theory, the more Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples you visit, the greater the blessing you receive, but whether you visit shrines or temples doesn't really matter.

sen.j: 例えば西日本の一部地域の様に「三社参り」などと言って正月三が日の内に複数（多くは三社程度）の神社に参拝するのが習慣となっている地域もある。
sen.e: For example, in some areas in the western Japan, there is a custom called "sanja-mairi" in which one pays visits to different shrines (about three shrines in most cases) during the first three days of the New Year.

For example, in some regions in the western Japan, there is a custom called 'sanja-mairi' in which people visit different shrines (about three shrines in most cases) during the first three days of the New Year.

For example, in some regions in the western Japan, there is a custom called 'sanja-mairi' in which people visit different shrines (about three shrines in most cases) during the first three days of the New Year.

sen.j: 前述の通り、神仏習合の思想が大きく影響していると考えられているためである。
sen.e: This results from the profound influence of the concept of syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism, as mentioned above.
This results from the profound influence of the concept of syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism, as mentioned above.
This results from the profound influence of the concept of syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism, as mentioned above.
